description: Erection of single storey rear replacement conservatory (3.225m in depth, maximum height of 3.575m and eaves height of 2.3m)
decision_conditions: The proposed extension and alterations are considered to fall within the parameters of permitted development as set out under Schedule 2, Part 1, Class A of the Town and County Planning (General Permitted Development) (England) Order 2015.

Condition 5 (Construction Management Details)- The applicant is reminded that no construction-related vehicles (including those belonging to private contractors) are permitted to park on any residential road in the vicinity of the site, other than in a pay-and display bay in accordance with any time restrictions. Wherever possible, contractors should travel by public transport, walking or cycling.The applicant is advised that it is their responsibility to ensure that all relevant highways permits (e.g. scaffolding, hoarding, oversailing, tower crane) and temporary traffic management orders as may be required are put in place at the appropriate times.If the means of construction vehicle access entails vehicles crossing the public footway (including use of an existing vehicle crossover) the applicant must contact the Highways Crossover Officer to determine whether a strengthened crossover is required.No work must be undertaken on the public highway without a Section 278 agreement being in place. No materials must be stored on the public highway unless this has been expressly permitted by RBK Highways. The applicant has indicated that all loading and unloading will occur on-site and a booking system will be in place to ensure that construction vehicles will not wait on Verona Drive or other nearby residential roads.The applicant should also contact the Highways Inspections Team to arrange for a highway condition survey to be undertaken before commencing these works.RBK Highways may from time to time advise the applicant that changes should be made to the routing of construction traffic and the applicant must abide by any such requests, even where these represent a departure from what has been previously stated in the CMP/CLP.
